Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2013 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Benjamin Linowitz is "Spectral Geometry of Arithmetic Manifolds." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Gopal Prasad.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the period of the PI's Postdoctoral Research Fellowship the PI wrote 12 papers concerning the geometry of arithmetically defined manifolds. Several of these papers resolved open conjectures in the field, and all involved the application of techniques from number theory. These techniques have allowed the PI to obtain precise quantitative results in a number of settings where such results were previously unknown. Additionally, the PI wrote a paper which applied techniques from algebraic number theory to the study of space time codes, an area of active research in computer science. The PI also supervised 3 undergraduate research students. One of these students is now a graduate student at Stanford University. The other two students wrote a joint paper which has since been published by the Journal of Number Theory. These students later presented their work at the 2014 Automorphic Forms Workshop in Moab, UT.

The PI also deepened his students’ understanding of the undergraduate mathematics curriculum by incorporating a variety of inquiry based learning methods into the freshmen honors seminar on Cryptology that he taught at the University of Michigan. In particular the PI worked to foster a supportive atmosphere where students are encouraged to communicate their ideas. In order to continue his development as an effective educator the PI worked extensively with the Unviersity of Michigan's Center for Inquiry Based Learning.
